reviews.review_text: This book took me by surprise. I saw the movie years ago and knew how vicious Bateman was, but I was definitely disturbed by some chapters. Other than that, it was mostly entertaining. I would write more, but I have to return some video tapes.

The movie and the book are not the same mood. Aiming for --that mood-- this book is not that thing.Other than that, Wow what a book! Disturbing in places, not to spoiler, he is definitely off his rocker in the book.

The writing is good, Ellis is talented, but the endless lists (a plot device I soon found annoying) and breakdown of items purchased were a little tedious. The psychosis of the main character was believable and you almost find yourself rooting for him as he murders his pretentious associates. I would not go so far to call this a classic, but maybe...it does encapsulate a time period rather well and with its ludicrously bloody murders and the killers ability to evade arrest or even suspicion for so long highlights the eras self-involved, consumer oriented, you-are-what-you-wear culture. I enjoyed it and read it pretty quickly, and I still recall it very well though it's been quite a long time since I finished it. worth a look and maybe a good entry point for Ellis newbies.but a Broadway play? really? Well it's better material than Spiderman I suppose.
Really good book. Worth the listen.

summary: In American Psycho, Bret Easton Ellis imaginatively explores the incomprehensible depths of madness and captures the insanity of violence in our time or any other. Patrick Bateman moves among the young and trendy in 1980s Manhattan. Young, handsome, and well educated, Bateman earns his fortune on Wall Street by day while spending his nights in ways we cannot begin to fathom. Expressing his true self through torture and murder, Bateman prefigures an apocalyptic horror that no society could bear to confront.
